topic.para: This topic describes how to examine TLS certificates.

section.title: How do I examine a TLS certificate?
section.para: To review a server certificate that is available locally as a file, use the following command:
section.screen: &prompt.user;openssl x509 -in server.crt -noout -text Certificate: Data: Version: 3 (0x2) Serial Number: 6a:43:f5:55:ef:03:ee:0e:23:c8:99:82:71:39:f2:22:1a:da:53:db Signature Algorithm: ecdsa-with-SHA256 Issuer: C = CZ, ST = Some-State, L = Prague, O = Example organization, CN = www.example.org, emailAddress = wilber@example.org Validity Not Before: Apr 15 09:30:31 2024 GMT Not After : May 15 09:30:31 2024 GMT Subject: C = CZ, ST = Some-State, L = Prague, O = Example organization, CN = www.example.org, emailAddress = wilber@example.org Subject Public Key Info: Public Key Algorithm: id-ecPublicKey Public-Key: (256 bit) pub: 04:7e:ad:12:c7:04:68:ea:d8:7d:a3:3a:ad:3d:79: [...] ASN1 OID: prime256v1 NIST CURVE: P-256 X509v3 extensions: X509v3 Subject Alternative Name: DNS:*.&exampledomain2;, DNS:&exampledomain2; X509v3 Key Usage: Digital Signature, Key Encipherment X509v3 Extended Key Usage: TLS Web Server Authentication Signature Algorithm: ecdsa-with-SHA256 30:46:02:21:00:a8:4f:7d:16:f2:93:01:b9:3d:31:e3:c6:6c: [...]

callout.para: Describes who issued the certificate. It shows only the parent-level issuer, not the top-level issuer from the certificate chain.

Describes the server that uses the certificate. The CN (Common Name) attribute was traditionally used to hold the fully qualified domain name of the server. While it can contain wildcards (for example, *.&exampledomain2;), its use for server identification is deprecated. Modern clients use the Subject Alternative Name extension instead.

This extension is used to identify the server and is required by modern web browsers. If this extension is present, it is used instead of the subject's CN. It can contain multiple DNS: entries for domain names and IP: entries for IP addresses.
Specifies purposes for which the certificate can be used.

section.title: How do I download server TLS certificate files?
section.para: The following command downloads just the server certificate from the example server suse.com. Replace it with the domain name of the server you want to examine.
Most public servers use several subordinate CAs in the certificate chain. To download the whole certificate chain into individual files, use the following command:
section.screen: &prompt.user;echo | openssl s_client -showcerts -connect suse.com:443 2>/dev/null \ | awk -v RS="-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----" \ 'NR>1{sub(/-----END CERTIFICATE-----.*/,"-----END CERTIFICATE-----"); \ print RS$0>NR-1".pem"}'
section.para: The command writes all certificate files named increasingly 1.pem, 2.pem and so on, up to the last certificate in the chain.

section.title: How do I verify the whole TLS certificate chain?
section.para: The client host normally has a collection of root CAs and verifies the server certificates against them. But the certificate that the server provides can be a subordinate CA. To trust the server's certificate, the client needs to verify its complete . The server sends all certificates as part of its Server Hello message and you can download them as described in .
The openssl command uses the -subject_hash and -issuer_hash options to retrieve the subject and issuer hashes from a certificate, for example:

The client compares the issuer hash 2401d14f with the issuer hashes of its collection of root CAs. In this case, no root CA has an issuer hash of 2401d14f. As the client cannot trust the server yet, it has to verify the other certificates from the chain as well. Notice that the next certificate in the chain has the -subject_hash identical to the -issuer_hash from the server certificate.

If the discovered issuer certificate is valid, you can trust the server as much as you trust the root CAs in your client certificate store.
To confirm that the certificate is a root CA, check its subject and issuer hashes. Because root CA certificates are self-signed, they have both hashes identical.
